Entry.1:
EL. BURG 

New Years Day dawned cold & dull. Slept in & had mail brought to Bivouac. Letters from home etc also 4 parcels. Rained nearly all day blew like H___. Had good dinner on parcels. Got wet outside - Biv dry.
Rained all night.
Moving back tomorrow
Entry.2:
Still showery & cold. Horses expected about 10 am.
Beautiful scene in valley with hills behind.
Packed up & horses arrived about 10.am
Moved at 12.30.
Arrived at 3 pm. Camped for night. Walked 1½ mile for feed for horse. Fine night.
L/Cpl. of S.P.1st time.
Horse lost.
Ground very muddy
Entry.3:
Moved at 9 am for Katra. Horse found. Met Dave on the way.

KATRA 
Arrived about 1 pm after passing thro Station Junction. Great improvements here to when we passed thro.
Went over to Divsn at night to see Dave. Had long yarn. He is off toCairo tomorrow.
Our destination isBELAH

 1918 Friday 4January

KATRA 
Beautiful day. Camped on sandy soil 1 mile from village.
Off tomorrow.

 1918 Saturday, 5January

Left Katra 9.30 am
travelled about 8 miles on our way back to Belah.
Roads awful. Mud & slush. Arrived at camp called Esdud.
Rained heavily during night. Got wet again

 1918 Sunday, 6January

Left Esdud
Still raining. Roads very bad. Slushy & muddy. Boggy ground. Wadi in flood.
Stream running at good rate. Arrived 
MIJIL
MEDJIL pitched Bivouac in rain.
Poured all night. Storm & gale. Thunder & lightning.

 1918 Monday, 7January

Left MEDJIL 8.30 am
Showery all day roads bad.
Got near sand travelling better.
Arrived back of Gaza& camped. Very pretty sight from hill. Turkish trenches everywhere & big shell holes. Fine night except for fewlight showers.

 1918 Tuesday, 8January

Left Gaza 8.30. Shower came on just as we left & did not rain after.
Rode thro Gaza. Place in ruins & deserted. Shell holes everywhere buildings smashed & houses demolished. Saw traces of early Roman architecture. Naval guns did most of damage. Cleared up & did not rain again.

Arrived BELAH 1.30 on sand near beach. Very pretty spot.

 1918 Wednesday, 9January

BELAH 
Settled in camp. Lovely spot close to sea & food & water.
Preparing for a long stay. Ord Cpl today. Mail in.

 1918 Thursday, 10January

BELAH

Settled down to usual camp routine.

 1918 Friday, 11January

Belah

 1918 Saturday, 12January

Belah

 1918 Sunday, 13January

Belah

 1918 Monday, 14January

Belah

 1918 Tuesday, 15January

Belah

Dave was over today. Had a chat to him. I was on guard.

 1918 Wednesday, 16January

Belah

Went over to see Dave. He is off to Cairo.

 1918 Thursday, 17January

Belah

 1918Friday, 18January

Belah

 1918 Saturday 19 January

This date 2 years we came home the longest way from town . Do you remember?

BELAH

Inspected in lines by Genl Hodgson & staff also ½ hour later by Brig Genl Wilson & staff.

 1918Sunday, 20January

Belah

 1918Monday, 21January

Belah
Entry.4:
Bgde
Inspected by Lt Gen Chauvel near B.H.Q. (dismounted)

Col Todd receives a bar to his D.S.O.

 1918Tuesday, 22January

Belah

JAR birthday

Drill started today

 1918Wednesday, 23January

Belah

Drill again

 1918Thursday, 24January

Belah

Delousing today.

I was R.O.C. & did not go (thank goodness).

Mail in today.

 1918Friday, 25January

Belah

Concert by Lancashires tonight

 1918Saturday, 26January

Belah

 1918 Sunday, 27January

Belah

On guard

 1918 Monday, 28January

Drill

 1918Tuesday, 29January

Belah

Drill
Saw Australian Football.
Put horse over jump.

 1918Wednesday, 30January

Belah

Fatigue
S.P.

 1918Thursday, 31January

Belah

Fatigue
Entry.5:
Bge concert. Very good.
Saw RSM Finlayson
Entry.7:
Belah

 1918Saturday, 2February

Belah

Guard

 1918Sunday, 3February

Belah

Guard

 1918Monday, 4February

Belah

 F.
Moving to Gaza tomorrow on salvaging operations.

 1918Tuesday, 5February

Belah

S.P.

Went to Gaza left Belah 7 am. arrived Gaza 8.30. Worked
Entry.8: 1-3. Salvage. Removing Gal. Iron & Timber from dugouts & trenches. Evidence of terrific bombardment. Shell cases, shrapnel, pieces of shells everywhere. Took snapshots of graves of Tommies killed Samsons Ridge
Entry.9:
First intended to shift camp to Gaza but later decided to work the job from here. Better idea.

 1918Wednesday, 6February

Belah

Off to Gaza again on salvage work. Very cold & windy. Saw many graves of those who fell at Samsons Ridge.
Went over to Turkish trenches at Umbrella Hill. They are blown to pieces.
Saw Ali Muntar hill which overlooks all positions.
Came back at dusk.

 1918Thursday, 7February

Belah

Off to Gaza. Very cold & windy.
Place covered with shrapnel, iron, bullets & pieces of shell cases.

 1918Friday, 8February

Belah

Rained like hell.
Rehearsal for Duke of Connaughts inspection to have taken place. It was cancelled owing to rain & we had to go to Gaza instead. Wadis running very strong.
I stayed with horses, rained all day & very cold.
On S.P. tonight rained all night.

 1918Saturday, 9February

Belah

Early reveille & it is raining very hard. Off to Gaza again.
Cancelled owing to rain.
We stayed in camp today. Rainedand blew in squalls. Had a bit of sunshine for about 3 hours.
Wrote a few letters tonight.

 1918Sunday, 10February

Belah

Still raining in squalls. Church parades cancelled owing to rain.
At Breakfast time a terrific hailstorm came & a very heavy shower afterwards. Horses very frightened.
Rained all day.

 1918Monday, 11February

(don't forget Mums birthday
Entry.10:
Fine day. Rain all gone.
Rehearsal for Duke of Connaughts inspection.
Genl Hodgson kept us out on parade till nearly 2 pm. He is very much disliked by A.M. Div. His nickname is "Shino".



 1918Tuesday, 12February

Many happy returns of the Day.

Stayed in camp today. Others went to Gaza.

 1918Wednesday, 13February

Belah

Left camp 1 am to go for remounts to Belah Stn. Train arrived at 4 am. Got back to camp 7 am with 38 remounts.

 1918Thursday, 14February

Belah

Others went to Gaza. I stayed in camp.
Had clean transport harness. Very short of men.Marched down as trooper under Sig. Corpl.
Genl Hodgson wants every bolt & link on all harness cleaned. Transport drivers won't do it.
Damn Hodgson.

 1918Friday, 15February

Belah

Another rehearsal for Duke of Connaught visit. Not so bad as last.

More remounts arrived today.

 1918Saturday, 16February

Belah

In camp. Others out to Gaza.

Fine day.

 1918Sunday, 17February

Camp all day.

 1918Monday, 18February

Belah

In camp all day.

Saw Dave for few minutes. He is back at
Entry.11:
again.

 1918Tuesday, 19February

Belah

Out to Gaza. Our last day there as salvaging nearly finished.

 1918Wednesday, 20February

Belah

 1918Thursday, 21February

Belah

Usual camp routine

 1918Friday, 22February

Belah

 1918Saturday, 23February

Belah

 1918Sunday, 24February

Belah

Went over to see Dave

 1918
Entry.12:
1918Tuesday, 26February

Belah

Shooting Rifle range

 1918Wednesday, 27February

Belah

Shooting Rifle range

 1918Thursday, 28February

Belah

1st day of our sports dismounted events

Aust Mtd Div big sports meeting

 1918
Entry.14:
Belah

3rd Brigade sports mounted

Good days sports

 1918
Entry.18:
Belah

Divisional Sports Dismounted

 1918Thursday, 7March

Belah

Race meeting of military horses

 1918
Entry.19:
1918Saturday, 9March

Belah

Divisional Sportsmounted events. A Good days sport.
Entry.20: Brigade Top the listof the Division.
Entry.21:
Regt. top the list of Regts in Division.



 1918
Entry.23:
Mtd Brigade concert. Very good.

 1918Tuesday, 12March

Belah

Another rehearsal for Duke of Connaughts visit

 1918
Entry.24:
1918Thursday, 14March

Belah

Inspection & presentation of Medals & Decorations by Duke of Connaught.

The whole Aust Mtd Div present on parade. Rode past in troop column with rifles unslung.

 1918Friday, 15March

Belah

Rained all day & night

 1918Saturday, 16March

Belah

Races at Gaza poured all day. I went. Backed few winners. Lost horse, got another then found mine again; someone else had him so we changed.

 1918Sunday, 17March

Belah

 1918Monday, 18March

Field Day

 1918Tuesday, 19March

Concert very good

 1918Wednesday, 20March

Concert by HAC very good.

Field Day

 1918Thursday, 21March

Another concert

 1918Friday, 22March

Belah

Out grazing all morning beautiful day

 1918
Entry.26:
1918Monday, 25March

Belah

Raining& windy
Going out to Gaza again.
Cancelled owing to rain

 1918Tuesday, 26March

Belah

Gaza today

 1918
Entry.27:
1918Thursday, 28March

On Guard

 1918Friday, 29March Good Friday

Belah

Field day

 1918Saturday, 30March

Field Day (Bayonet charging)

 1918Sunday, 31March

Belah

Leaving here tomorrow. Went to Com. this morning.

Rumours that we are to push up the coast. N of Jaffa.

 1918
Entry.28:
Belah Last day

Busy packing up
Left Camp at 3 pm travelled to near Gaza. Camped for night.
Camp site & rations & fodder waiting for us. A party precedes the Brigade & selects & marks out the camp.

 1918Tuesday, 2April

Grazing horses all morning. H__ of a long way for water.
Left at 12.30 travelled 15 miles through Deir Seneid to Medjil where we camped.
Another long trip to water. Dark when horses returned.
Great concentration of troops. Like a city all night with all the lights. Beautiful weather.

 1918 Wednesday, 3April

Left Medjil 12.30. travelled about 10 or 11 miles. Camped 
near
 between Esdud & Ascalon (Yebna).
Pulled in to camp at 2.45 pm. Beautiful day & pleasant travelling.

 1918Thursday, 4April

Left camp 11.30 Arrived Deiran at 3.30 beautiful sight from hill. Could see Deiran, several villages to Ramleh.

 1918
Entry.29:
Left Deiran 1200 arrived Selmeh 4 miles E Jaffa 4.30 pm.

Saw Taubes high up. Can hear guns from here also see Hills round Jerusalem very plainly.

 1918 Saturday, 6April

Went to Jaffa in party mounted, rotten trip, only 20 minutes leave.

All interesting parts out of bounds, English troops rule the roost. APMs & MPs everywhere. Aussies can't expect anything better from the Tommy heads. Our General & his staff are English. Nuff sed.

 1918 Sunday, 7April

Selmeh 

Went up to River Auja with Padre to find a NZ grave then rode thro Sarona & into Jaffa.

Sarona was German Colony. Very neat little suburb & very clean.

 1918 Monday, 8April

Selmeh

Went into Jaffa - rotten hole. Everywhere out of bounds. Very little change to be had - so purchasing is difficult. People are keeping all the silver they can get.

 1918 Tuesday, 9April

Selmeh

Nothing doing

 1918 Wednesday, 10April

Selmeh

Nothing doing

 1918 Thursday, 11April

Selmeh

Went over to see Dave. He is very upset.

 1918 Friday, 12April

Selmeh

Full dress parade.

Went over to see Dave again.

 1918 Saturday, 13April

Selmeh



 1918 Sunday, 14April

Selmeh

Could hear terrific bombardment last night 9.15 pm. Shells lit up the sky.

 1918 Monday, 15April

Selmeh

Rumours of a move in a few days.

 1918 Tuesday, 16April

Mum's birthday

Selmeh

 1918 Wednesday, 17April

Selmeh

Rode over to see Dave at night.

 1918 Thursday, 18April

Selmeh

Rode over to Muleibis about 8 miles. Very prosperous village great orchards - almonds oranges lemons etc. Country very prosperous looking.

Leaving here tomorrow for Jericho direction.

Noticed the Blue Gums growing in almost every village. Plenty here also Katreh & elsewhere. Just like NSW.

 1918 Friday, 19April

Selmeh to Deirain. 9.30 to 2 pm

Left Selmeh at 9.30 am country nearly all under cultivation. Arabs ploughing or fallowing. Same old antiquated methods.

Arrived outside Deiran at 2 pm & camped. Very dusty trip but weather good.

 1918 Saturday, 20April

Deiran to Latron 8.30 to 3.30

Left Deiran 8.30 am. Country similar to yesterday. Roads dusty owing to traffic. Arrived at Latron 3.30 pm. Great difference in country to when we were here before & after Xmas. Green everywhere. Roads still dusty.

Rode thro village of Deiran. It is very prosperous looking. Modern houses all red tiles everywhere. Saw some pretty girls.

 1918 Sunday, 21April

Latron to Enab 8.30 to 2 pm

Left Latron 8.30 am & started our climb once more up the pass. Recognisedall our old camping sites, which are now covered with grass.
Arrived Enab 2 pm. Plenty of water in wells & creeks. Not like our first trip. Good weather good travelling.

Jericho road like this

Heat very oppressive.

 1918 Monday, 22April

Enab to Talat Dumm 7 am to 4 pm

Left Enab 7 am. Travelled over same old road as on our entry to Jerusalem. Great alteration in country. Everywhere green. Not to halt in Jerus., worse luck.

Halted just outside Jerusalem at 10.30. Fed up & boiled billies. Moved off at 11.15 went thro Jerus. without a stop. Turned off on Jericho Rd. Skirted round walls of Holy City. Passed Garden of Gethsemane. Church with golden domes here. Road white with dust. Road wound & twisted high & low between awful hills. Country looks awful so far. Giant steep hills, no cover of any kind. Bivouac in old camel camp. All white when we arrived.

 1918 Tuesday, 23April

(Ascent of Blood) Talat el Dumm 

Dead Sea below level 1292 ft below sea level Jerus. 2720 ft above sea level.

Camped just off the Jericho Road between gianthills. Place absolutely barren & full of small stones. Climbed highest hill. Saw Dead Sea, Jordan & valley & Jericho & Jerus. at back. Magnificent sight. Country very rough & hilly. Water pumped up from gully below in 2 relays. Very hot & dusty. Hills mostly white chalk. Glare very bad. Great traffic on Jericho Rd.

 1918 Wednesday,24April

Salat el Dummto Jericho

Left here at 7 am watered & travelled in ½sections down to Jericho Road. White dust & hills also white chalk. Very hot. Arrived foot of Jericho Rd. at 11 am. Camped 4 m. NW Jericho under Temptation Hill. Greek orthodox monastery & village built on cliff half way up hill. Top of hill walled in.

Magnificent wild & rugged scenery. Giant hills. Very little vegetation. Very hot in day cold at night. Flies bad.

Plenty of water. Small creek fast running only 100 yds away. Stony country, valley of Jordan about 15 miles wide.

 1918 Thursday, 25April

Jericho

Warm day but dusty.
Rode thro town to canteen very ordinary place. Met some chaps from I.C.C. 
Temptation hill is where J.C. fasted 40 days & 40 nights& where he was tempted by Devil.

 1918 Friday, 26April

Jericho

Horse lame -sent to sick lines.

Went up to Mount of Temptation very stiff climb. Looked thro Greek Monastery of St George. It is built in the face of a cliff halfway up the mount. Good view of great gorges & ravines. Great view of valley of Jordan & Dead Sea from top of walls on crest of hill.
Pretty farm in valley at foot of hill. Great sight of ranges other side of Jordan. Could also see Jerus. & Mt of Olives.

 1918 Saturday, 27April

Jericho

Nothing doing.

Very hot during day. Cool but dusty in afternoon. Heat most enervating.

 1918 Sunday, 28April

Jericho

Nothing doing.
Went over to see Dave.
Entry.30:
1918 Monday, 29April

Moved out from Jericho at dusk en route for Es Salt. Rode down across the pontoon bridge over theJordan in terrific dust. Most horses very frightened at the swinging of the bridge which only had hessian sides. Half the column got lost in the dust & rode almost under the hills of Jordan. Turks had the wind up. Star shells everywhere & heavy artillery opened at random.
Entry.31:
Div. are attacking the Road. The lost columns met before dawn & concentrated under lee of hills. 4th Brigade heavily shelled in the valley. We were white with dust after our night ride, mostly at gallop.

 1918 Tuesday, 30April

We start our long arduous climb up the hills (riding & leading) on to Es Salt.. Several minor accidents of horses falling, some men injured. My horse is like a goat. Arrived on top of hills which surround Es Salt.
Entry.32: L.H. holding a position. "B" Sqdn of
Entry.33:
detailed for a bayonet charge. We hop over under barrage from machine gun fire, down a steep rocky hill & up other side. Turks entrenched but we carry the position.I & 2 others finish off 6 in a trench. It is nearly dark but we have some good shooting. 50 odd prisoners taken. We do outpost after

 1918
Entry.34:
Mollie's birthday

Turks attack at 3 am & "B" Sqdrn are sent to reinforce
Entry.35:
L.H. We only have a few rocks for cover & there are only of us here. Fighting very close & several casualties occur. I do some bombing, crawled out in front & settled a machine gun & crew. At 8 am they surrendered. 518 Turks came in. About 200 of them were left out in front dead. We can see another battalion coming to attack so we rebuild our defences. We are relieved & go back to our outpost line. At night we go into Es Salt to water then do outpost.

 1918
Entry.36: After outpost we advance along the road & take up new outpost line but are driven back. We take up another position & hold till dusk & we leave the town. We are surrounded & are led by a Bedouin down an old wadi which leads to the Jordan. We emerge at daylight & are heavily shelled. We got back to the Jordan safely. Water & have a bite to eat & fall asleep. This was our first sleep since
Entry.37:
We left here at dark for Jericho.

 1918 Friday, 3May

Arrived Jericho about mid-night, tie horses up & sleep till 8 am, all dead beat. Horses still lying down when we got up.

We rested all day in the open. The heat, flies, dust & other pests are awful.

 1918 Monday, 6May

We move up to relieve
Entry.38:
L.H. Bge W of Jordan on the Auja.

Some tall snake yarns were spread about, & all were uneasy. Several snakes killed in this locality.

We dig funk holes for protection against aircraft.

Heat terrific.

 1918
Entry.46:
1918 Wednesday,15May

Hot day

Went up to trenches at 6.39. Sapping from 7 till 10 pm on ½hour shifts.

Very tired.

Too hot to work in daytime so we walk from camp, across the Jordan, up the steep banks other side & return to camp after working. Number of men getting sick.

 1918 Thursday, 16May

Working Sapping from 4 am till 7 am. Very tired.

Very hot day, dull & muggy.

 1918 Friday, 17May

The Jordan valley - the valley of death.

Too tired & worn out to write.

Most awful place.

Heat, dust, flies, mosquitoes, scorpions, hornets, wasps ants & snakes.

Cold winds early in the mornings.

 1918 Saturday,18May

Valley of death

 1918
Entry.47:
1918 Monday, 20May

Still the vally of death - no respite.

Work, work, work,

Our daily climb to the trenches E of Jordan.

Sapping & wiring.

 1918
Entry.48:
1918 Wednesday,22May

Trenches again. We are living in them for a while. Soft crumbly soil - dirty always. We go down to the Jordan for a swim daily. River flowing very fast & most difficult to cross. Dirty muddy water which we have to drink. We get dirty crossing back. Eating living & sleeping in dust & dirt.

 1918 Thursday, 23May

Trenches E of Jordan.

Outpost at night, eaten alive with mosquitoes every night. Men going away with malaria every day. Our Regt. getting depleted.

 1918 Friday, 24May

Trenches

 1918 Saturday, 25May

Trenches

 1918 Sunday, 26May

Trenches - we have to go back to the horses every morning to take them to water & feed them. We have very few men now owing to malaria & sandfly fever & dysentery. We return to trenches at 6 am & then do outpost & listening post. We average 5 hours sleep per night. I am too dead beat for the mosquitoes to keep me awake. Can't sleep in daytime owing to flies.

Jordan valley an absolute nightmare.

 1918 Monday, 27May

Trenches

 1918 Tuesday, 28May

Trenches

 1918 Wednesday,29May

Still up in the trenches at night & to & from the horses during the day. Men still going away to Hospital with malaria.

My eyes are getting very bad. No sign of malaria - hope not. Horses are having a bad time.

 1918
Entry.53:
Air raid by 8 Taubes & Gothas at 5 am. Ideal day for them. Low clouds. Large number of horses knocked. Very few men. I was on listening post when they flew over. They dropped right out of the clouds & flew very low. Quite a surprise visit which lasted nearly an hour bombing & machine gunning.

 1918
Entry.56:
Valley of death

 1918 Friday, 7June

Jordan valley

 1918 Saturday, 8June

Valley of death

 1918 Sunday, 9June

Valley of death

Back under the Mount of Temptation once more.

 1918
Entry.58:
1918 Wednesday, 12June

In Jerusalem waiting for the wide guage railway to be completed so I could get to Cairo.

 1918 Thursday,13June

Left Jerusalem for Cairo

 1918 Friday,14June

Arrived Cairo - stayed at Cecil House.

 1918Saturday,15June

Cairo

Met Oliver Hogue. Was out driving with him all the afternoon.

He looks well.

 1918 Sunday,16June

Cairo

Feeling ill - very feverish - cannot eat.

Don't know what's the matter. Probably touch of the sun.

 1918 Monday,17June

Cairo

Very sick. In bed all day.

Madame (of Cecil House) rang up AIF Hqrs.

Ambulance came round. Taken to
Entry.59:
Genl Hosp right away. Temp 104.8.

 1918 Tuesday,18June

Feeling bit better. Temp down to 100°

Temp up to 105 at night. Was delirious.

 1918 Wednesday,19June

Hospital. Blood test proves I have M.T. Malaria.

 1918 Thursday, 20June

Hospital

 1918 Friday, 21June

Hospital

 1918 Saturday, 22June

Hospital

 1918 Sunday, 23June

Hospital

 1918 Monday, 24June

Hospital
Entry.60:
June

Hospital

 1918 Wednesday, 26June

Hospital

 1918 Thursday, 27June

Hospital

 1918 Friday, 28June

Hospital

 1918 Saturday, 29June

Hospital

 1918 Sunday, 30June

Hospital

 1918
Entry.75:
1918 Tuesday,16 July

Hospital

Had leave from Hosp.

Cabled Jeanne also Kath.

 1918
Entry.81:
1918Wednesday, 24July

Hosp.

Dave came out to see me this morning.

Cable from Jeanne arrived 3.30 pm.

 1918Thursday, 25July

Dave came out today also.

 1918
Entry.94:
Left Boulac for Moascar 11 am arrived 2.30.

 1918Friday, 9August

Moascar

Saw Bob Fell, Harry Greenberg, Ernie Baker.

 1918Saturday,10August

Going up other end of Camp for a months school for NCOs under Capt Dickenson.

Saw C J Stamm.

 1918
Entry.113:
1918Friday, 30August

Exams of NCOs school today.

 1918Saturday, 31August

School finished. Got first class pass.

Came back to details after refusing an offer to stay as an instructor.

 1918
Entry.115:
Marching out to Regt tomorrow.

 1918Tuesday, 3September

Marched out today

Train left Moascar

 1918
Entry.116:
1918Thursday, 5September

Arrived at the Regt. which is at Ludd. We are to be turned into cavalry & have swords issued. Also rifle buckets no more carrying rifles.

 1918Friday, 6September

Ludd

 1918Saturday, 7September

Ludd - learning how to use the swords.

 1918
Entry.120:
1918Thursday,12 September

Ludd

 1918Friday,13 September

Ludd still drilling with swords both mounted & dismounted.

 1918Saturday,14 September

Ludd

Went to Con

 1918Sunday,15 September

Ludd

Went to Comm

 1918
Entry.122:
1918Wednesday,18 September

Left Ludd 7 pm on the big stunt (moonlight).

Camped at 9.25 near Jaffa-Sarona.

 1918
Entry.123:
Awakened at dawn by big bombardment

Left Sarona 9 am travelled at trot North & halted at 8 pm had a sleep till 12.30 am. Moved off at 1 am "D" Troop part of screen away out on the plains on our own.

Travelling very dusty & hot.

 1918Friday, 20September

NE by E

Travelled thro the morn till 11.30 am. Halted, had lunch, a wash & rest at Lejin.

Afoule captured by yeomanry & Indians. Great number of prisoners coming in, including Boches.

Left Warakanyeh 4.30 "B" Sqdn in lead. Travelled at trot across plain (IOM) of Esdraelon to Jenin. Enemy immediately fired dumps barracks aerodromes on sighting us. Went in without opposition.

 1918Saturday, 21September

Great haul of prisoners. "B" Sqdn got 7000 Turks & Germans & German officers & staff. Lot of other prisoners got by
Entry.124:
outside Jenin with armoured cars on right supporting. Great stores of Champagne wine rum spiritsfood & gold. German band also taken. Scarcely a shot fired. I was thro the town digging up prisoners. Got field glasses revolvers galore. Came out & picketed prisoners from 11 pm until daylight. Had breakfast & observation post.

Did outpost next day.

 1918Sunday, 22September

Counted prisoners as they marched 6800.

Up on Observation post. From conversation with Turks & Germans there is great animosity between the two races.

Observation Post all day, not relieved till 5 pm should have been relieved at 3 pm. Brigade has moved out. After watering we left at 6.15 to follow them. Halted at 9.15 at the Afouleh. Camped near
Entry.125:
Transport till daylight.

 1918Monday, 23September

Left Afouleh at 5.30 am to look for Regt. Passed thro big Station Junction then saw Brigade Hqrs. Kept going & found Regt at near Mt Tabor near Railway line to Valley of Jordan. After a few hours rest "B" Sqdn saddled up & moved out to intercept some Turks reported moving N. Did not see them so came back to Regt.

Camped that night.

 1918Tuesday, 24September

Moved down towards Jordan Valley. Picked up 4000 Turk prisoners. Escorted them back to Afouleh. Prisoners very sick. Some died on the way. Very slow travelling.

Picketed prisoners all night.

 1918Wednesday, 25September

At El Afouleh nearly all day.

Left El Afouleh 5.15. On to Tiberias. Climbed very steep track thro the hills. Zig Zag all the way. Came thro Nazareth at night dust blinding & choking. Seemed a very big town right on the hills. Zig Zag back down all the way. Halted at 10.45 pm for an hour, boiled the billy & moved off again.

 1918Thursday, 26September

Travelled thro the night. At Dawn we halted with the sea of Gallilee before us the N end of it. City of Tiberius hidden by hills. Jewish settlement here. Plenty of water.

Left here & camped on Lake of Tiberius. Swam horses & men.

Did outpost at night.

 1918Friday, 27September

Left Sea of Gallilee 8 am travelled up thro hills & along road to Damascus. Met Oliver Hogueat big Jewish village.

Pushed on to Jordan Crossing. Plenty rifle shots. Crossed Jordan at dark under fire. Rode up over awful stony country. Came across party of enemy on road who fired on us. Captured them. Did outpost then guarded prisoners. Several casualties & several horses shot in above scrap.

 1918Saturday, 28September

Had a few casualties during night. Lt Macnee & Lamond wounded, Tom Edwards killed. Self & three others had to take our prisoners back. Picked up some more at Jordan. Total 77, Went back to Jaauli with them. Got them into motors. Two men sent with them.

Camped at Desert Corps Hqrs for night. Two taubes bombed us this morning. No one hit. Had trouble with German spy named Wagner, with above lot of prisoners.

 1918Sunday, 29September

Left Desert Corps & Jaauli at 8 am. Went thro village bought bread & figs. Travelled along road chasing Regt pushed on till 11.30 pm. Camped alongside road. Regt out in front fighting. Indian CavalryDiv. Gen'l refused to let me go on till his Division had moved.

 1918Monday, 30September

Pushed on again at 7 am passed many prisoners and all transports etc.

Found Aus Div Hqrs & decamped with them after nightfall. 5000 odd prisoners just came in.

 1918
Entry.126:
Left Aust Div Hqrs 8 am travelled thro hills in track of Regt. Came thro pretty village on outskirts of Damascus. Awful sights. Shambles. Dead dying men & animals. Guns wagons etc strewn all along track. Came right thro Damascus. Chased Regt. found Brigade & camped for night. Regt only a mile away.

People of city clapped & cheered gave us fruit etc.

 1918
Entry.127:
Rejoined the Regiment just as they were moving out. Travelled at trot after a crowd of Turks & Germans. They surrendered. We pushed on thro several villages. Did not have any scrapping.

Came thro another village bought eggs & fowls. Came back to Bivouac. Eggs & bully for tea.

 1918Thursday, 3October

Early breakfast got potatoes & grapes.

"B" Sqdn left Regt came back thro Damascus. Right thro main street & Bazaars. Pretty city water running everywhere. Streets thronged with people who gave us fruit etc. Came along the road where the carnage was. Picked up batch of prisoners brought them back to a house put a guard on when a sqdn camped near by.

 1918Friday, 4October

Beautiful sight of Damascus where we are camped. Working parties of prisoners go out under escort to clear streams of dead etc. which are burnt. Animals, dead & waggons all burnt.

Back to camp for night.

 1918Saturday, 5October
Entry.128:
job as yesterday still clearing up the roads. Dead bodies cannot be buried so we have to burn them. Most gruesome job. The prisoners have to do this work which is nauseous to them as well as us. Stench of burning dead is most sickening.

Some of the boys went to hospital & very sick. We expect fever to break out. I am well so far.

 1918Sunday, 6October

Still on same job of escorting prisoners as yesterday, clearing up roads etc. We are living well on fruit. Tomatoes vegetables & fresh meat purchased with captured money.

Rained tonight so camped in an empty house plenty of fleas.

 1918Monday, 7October

Fine morning.

Still on same job. Awful smell. Bodies getting worse.

Fine night

Tuesday, 8
Entry.130:
Bge.

Came back to rejoin the Regiment at Kaukab 12 m from Damascus. Arrived 5 pm.

15000 prisoners here & our Regt guarding them. On guard over prisoners tonight.
Entry.131:
9October1918

Kaukab

On guard over prisoners. The Turk is the lowest human being I ever met.A great number sick. Dying at about 60 per day. Awful smells.

Each squadron as 5000 prisoners - all Turks

 Thursday,10October1918

Kaukab
Entry.132:
11October1918

Kaukab

Went round several villages looking for grain & tibbin, got 84 eggs.

On guard tonight. Stench from the Turks very putrid.
Entry.133:
1918

Kaukab

Nice weather. Still guarding the prisoners.

On guard over them tonight.
Entry.138:
1918

 Friday, 18 October1918

 Saturday, 19 October1918

 Sunday, 20October1918

Kaukab still guarding prisoners

 Monday, 21October1918

Kaukab

Received cable from Kath saying "Wedding 23 Oct".

 Tuesday, 22 October1918

 Wednesday, 23
Entry.139:
Kaths wedding day

Went to Damascus (riding) to take photos of Boydens grave. Returned to camp 12 MN.

Very dull day expect rain.

 Thursday, 24October 1918

Dads birthday.

Wet day, awfully boggy. Clothes wet.

On guard tonight. Rain easing off.

 Friday, 25October 1918

Kaukab

Dawned fine but more rain expected.

 Saturday, 26 October 1918

 Sunday, 27 October 1918

 Monday, 28October 1918

Kaukab

One of party escorting 500 prisoners to Railway line. Tommy escort failed to turn up so we had to go on train with them to El Hammil where Jacks blew up the bridge across stream. Beautiful scenery on way down. Zig Zag railway twisting & turning across bridges &viaducts & thro tunnels.

Camped here the night. We crossed seven bridges & viaducts & went thro seven tunnels on this journey.

 Tuesday, 29October 1918

El Hammil

Handed over to Indian Escort. Had breakfast & went down to the Hot Springs. Had a hot sulphur spring bath. Had a look at broken bridge took photo of it.

Left here on ration train at 1 pm. Very slow trip up. Arrived Diera 7 pm. Camped for night.

 Wednesday, 30
Entry.140:
Left Diera at 9.30 am. Train controlled from here by Mecca Arabs.

Met at station where we started from by our own horsemen at 2 pm. Regt moving out today.

Rode back to Kaukab packed up & left here at 5.15 pm. Remainder of Regt had moved on.

We caught them at 7 pm 6 miles on the road to Damascus. Camped here the night.

 Thursday, 31
Entry.141:
Reveille 5 am. Moved off at 7.30 am. Picked up C & A Sqdn who had been in Damascus doing picket duty & marched thro the town at 10 am.

Went out on same road as before & camped for night past Duma.
Entry.142:
Left here at 7.30 am on the road to Homs. All flat country along this road until the Mountains are reached then we climbed up a steady grade up & over the hills. On both sides were paralell ranges with fallen stone barricades right along.

Went right on to village where we halted about 3.30 pm for night. Plenty of water in a spring.
Entry.144:
Left village again at 7.30 am. Road branched to left into the hills which we crossed in one long trek (over 20 miles today). Kind of plateau on top of hills miles wide. Uninteresting scenery. Cocky farmers tilling the ground on top of hills.

Went right on to NEBKH. Bigger village than Jenin. Halted at 4.30 pm. Met a couple of women speaking English. Good weather so far. Watered at Orontes river. Huge ranges on left some peaks 10,000 ft high according to maps.
Entry.146:
NEBK

Revielle 4 am left 6.30 am long trek today. Uninteresting trip. Dusty road. Flat country.

Halted at Jenda village E of road at 5.30 pm. Watered at deep well.

 Monday, 4November 1918

Jenda 

Left at 6 am. After 2 hours travelling sighted lake about 4 mile W of road. Also sighted Homs.

Arrived here 12 noon marched right thro town & Brigade.

Heard here (official) about Turkey finished fighting. Camped here.

Wont be long now before Germany throws up the sponge. We have smashed the Turks.

 Tuesday, 5November 1918

HOMS

Melb. Cup day drew Earl of Clan in sweep.

Heard of Austria finished great rejoicing. Very busy drawing rations etc for trek to Tripoli tomorrow.

Lot of decorations out today. Hamlin DSO, Olden DSO, Richardson, Doig MC, Martin, Connolly, Hay DCM, Louden (Scouts) DCM.

Small mail in today.

Homs looks picturesque from distance fine mosque here.

 Wednesday, 6November 1918

HOMS

Left here 6 pm. Went thro Homs. Some of thecafes brilliantly lit up looks very modern, French ideas prominent, & travelled along road till 11 pm. Camped until 4.30 am.

Promoted T/Cpl.

 Thursday, 7November 1918

Off again at 6 am. Very cold. Strong wind blowing. Roads very dusty & stoney. Travelling thro hilly country very uninteresting. Came through a long valley between hills. Very fertile & fresh water, river running down middle of it. Watered at this river. Went about 2½ miles further & camped at 11 am. Still very windy. Village nearby.

 Friday, 8November 1918

Left 6.30 am. Cold & windy & very dusty. Road still hilly. Halted 10 am after watering for lunch.

Off again 11.30 am. On the plains now with range of hills on left, looking very picturesque. Plains dotted with habitations. Very fertile country. Mediterranean Sea sighted. Travelled along coast & halted near beach close to river. Gale increased in velocity. Dust & black sand plentiful. Camped here - few miles outside Tripoli.

Big range of hills (4 in number) at the back of us - The Mountains of Lebanon.

 Saturday, 9November 1918

Off at 7 am. Gale still blowing (behind us). Working parties all along road repairing it & getting ready for winter.

Suburbs of Tripoli reached. Tripoli sighted right on a point of the coast. We turned left & climbed thro upper Tripoli. Fine view of town from the heights. Arrived at camping site in hills above town about 11.30 am, in amongst the olive groves. Rich chocolate soil here - which will turn into beautiful mud when rain comes.

 Sunday, 10November 1918

Tripoli

Colonel not satisfied with present camp site. Moved this afternoonto spot in the olive trees abt. 500 yds away.

Name of nearest village Mishlaya (?). Proper name Medjelaya.

 Monday, 11November 1918

Mejdelaya Tripoli

Busy erecting bivouacs. Had another attack of malaria abt. 11 am. Started to rain after lunch.

Glorious news of Germany accepting armistice reached here abt. 6 pm. Flares going up everywhere. Guns booming. Sirens blowing & warships firing salutes in Tripoli bay. Church bells chiming. Great rejoicing.

Still raining. I had a severe attack of malaria but got up to cheer the news.

 Tuesday, 12November 1918

Tripoli

Still raining in thunder showers. Feeling bit better. Ground very boggy. Preparing for winter by issue of clothing, blankets etc.

Rained on & off all day.

 Wednesday, 13November 1918

Tripoli

Still raining. Feel OK today ground like quagmire above ankles on horse lines.

Rained all day on & off with thunder & lightning.

 Thursday, 14November 1939

Tripoli

Fine day but cold.

Snow on the ranges. My first sight of snow. Not so cold down here as we expected.

 Friday, 15November 1918

Tripoli

Still fine but cloudy. Tonight a storm passed over & went out to sea.

 Saturday, 16November 1918

Fine weather

 Sunday, 17November 1918

Fine weather continues.

 Monday, 18November 1918

Mejdelaya

 Tuesday, 19 November

 Wednesday, 20November 1918

Mejdelaya

 Thursday, 21 November

 Friday, 22November 1918

Mejdelaya

 Saturday, 23 November 1918

 Sunday, 24November 1918

Mejdelaya

 Monday, 25 November

 Tuesday, 26November 1918

Mejdelaya

 Wednesday, 27November 1918

Going to Cedars of Lebanon tomorrow.

pushed on thro the clouds which were below us. Crossed stream at Bisharie then dismounted & led horses up goat track - very rough. Mounted again on top & rode for a while. Reached Cedars after dark - rather cold. Snow on mts. above us. Had tea & turned in.

 Thursday, 28November 1918

Left camp 6 am. dull morning on route for Cedars of Lebanon. Travelled along good road which wound round the hills, climbing all the way. Passed thro villages all the way, from half way a fine view of Tripoli & sea. Had lunch by the way. In every village some people spoke English.

Beautiful scenery all the way. All the hillsides terraced off in stones & ploughed. Some crops already above ground. Poplar trees 70 ft high entwined with grape vines. All leaves turning to gold. Pine forest on side of one mountain. All sorts of colouring on rocks & soil. Arrived Bisharie 4 pm.

 Friday, 29
Entry.147: Up at 5 am left Cedars after daylight. Not many cedars left. One tree 39 ft in circumference. Beautiful sight of deep gorge after leaving Cedars. village on right left sheer cliff. Arrived Bisharie 8.15 had breakfast at Hotel left 10.15 am. Had look at Blowhole 1 m from "B" abt. 800 ft deep with waterfall. Lovely sight down the gorge. Clear day better view of Tripoli & country all dotted with villages. Fine rain started cleared off when we reached foot of hills. Arrived camp dark - glorious trip.
Entry.156:
Rain & mud & slush. The cultivated ground turned into a bog. Horses standing up to their hocks in mud. Several bivouacs under water. Some chaps sleeping on mud.

Whole camp a quagmire. Rainy season has set in in earnest.
Entry.158:
Rain

 Sunday, 8December 1918

Rain

 Monday, 9December 1918

Mejdelaya

Cleared up this morning

Tuesday, 10 December 1918

Took horses to beach Tripoli to wash mud off them. Had a swim.
Entry.159:
Tripoli

Busy erecting bivouacs. Had an attack of Malaria about 11 am. Feeling very off. Started to rain after lunch.

Glorious news of Germany accepting armistice reached here abt. 6 pm. Flares going up everywhere. Guns firing, warships in Tripoli fire salute. Church bells chimed. Great rejoicing.

See Nov.

Still raining. Ground very boggy. Shifting camp in couple of days.
Entry.160:
Tripoli

Still raining in thundery showers. Feeling bit better. Preparing for the winter, issue of winter clothing, blankets etc.

Ground like quagmires. Rained on & off all day.


see Nov.

Packing up today. Fine day. Left about 9 am arrived new camp 11 am right on beach. Sheltered spot rather pretty.
Entry.161:
Fine day. All busy building bivouacs & getting camp ship shape.

Another storm today plenty of rain.

Rained very heavily during night.
Entry.162:
Fine day - Had a swim good breakers.

Rained again during night.

No mud here as we are on the sand. Everything very clean.
Entry.163:
El Mina Tripoli

Light rain fell all day.

Camp tip top & clean
Entry.164:
Squally day - increased to a gale.

Rained all night again and today.
Entry.165:
Raining again. Thanksgiving day for finish of Armistice.

Squally all day.

Sort ofa holiday
Entry.169:
Sunday, 22 December

 Monday, 23December 1918

Rained all day bit cold also.

 Tuesday, 24
Entry.170:
Dull day. Rain eased off this morning.

On Tripoli picquet tonight from 5 pm till 9. Cold night but fine.

 Wednesday, 25
Entry.171:
Beautiful fine da.y

Spent a much happier Xmas than preceding ones. Plenty of food & beer for the Regt Officers & Sgts had a blow out.

Band here tonight.

 Thursday, 26
Entry.172: Fine day again. Try outs for the sports today.
